tools.label: Tools
tools.title: AMCR Maps - Mapping Tools
tools.tool1.title: Site Search
tools.tool1.description: Interactive map interface for searching archaeological sites by various criteria including period, find type and geographic location.
tools.tool2.title: Spatial Analysis
tools.tool2.description: Advanced tools for spatial analysis of archaeological data, including heatmaps and statistical visualizations.
tools.tool3.title: Data Layering
tools.tool3.description: Ability to combine different data layers for a comprehensive view of archaeological finds in context.
tools.tool4.title: Data Export
tools.tool4.description: Flexible options for exporting maps and data to various formats for further processing.
tools.tool5.title: Timeline
tools.tool5.description: Visualization of archaeological finds over time with the ability to animate settlement development.
tools.tool6.title: Sharing and Collaboration
tools.tool6.description: Share your maps and analyses with colleagues and the public via public links.
tools.tool7.title: Mobile Access
tools.tool7.description: Fully responsive interface allows you to work with maps on mobile devices directly in the field.
additionalServices.title: Other Components of AIS CR
additionalServices.description: Discover the complete range of services and tools of the Archaeological Information System of the Czech Republic.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: Where can I find information about archaeological excavations?
faq.a1: Information about archaeological excavations can be found in AMCR (Archaeological Map of the Czech Republic). The system contains records of projects, excavations, sites and documents from archaeological research. Data is publicly available through the web interface.
faq.q2: How can I become an amateur collaborator?
faq.a2: To register in the AMCR-PAS system, visit the AMCR-PAS page and fill out the registration form. After approval, you will gain access to report archaeological finds. Before registration, we recommend familiarizing yourself with the legal obligations of detectorists.
faq.q3: How do I find out if my area is part of an archaeological site?
faq.a3: Use the AMCR map interface, where you can search for your area by address or coordinates. The system will display all registered sites and archaeological excavations in the area. For an official statement, contact the relevant archaeological institution.
faq.q4: Is it necessary to report construction plans in areas with archaeological finds?
faq.a4: Yes, according to Act No. 20/1987 Coll. on state heritage care, it is necessary to report any plan that could endanger archaeological finds. You can submit the notification online through the AMCR form or contact the relevant archaeological institution.
faq.q5: Who conducts archaeological research during construction?
faq.a5: Archaeological research is carried out by an authorized archaeological organization based on permission from the Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic. A list of authorized organizations can be found on the AIS CR website. Research is conducted at the developer's expense.
faq.q6: Can laypeople view archaeological finds online?
faq.a6: Yes, in the AMCR Digital Archive, photos, plans and 3D models of archaeological finds are publicly available. Frequently cited documents are available for download. Additional materials can be obtained upon request.
faq.q7: How can I use AIS CR for my work?
faq.a7: AIS CR offers an API interface for machine data processing, the ability to export data to various formats and integration with GIS systems. For research purposes, you can request access to more detailed data. More information can be found in the documentation.
faq.a8: Most archaeological sites are not publicly accessible because they are located on private land or are protected. Some significant sites are accessible as archaeological parks or open-air museums. Information about the accessibility of a specific site can be obtained from the local museum or archaeological institute.
faq.a9: Regular updates, news and announcements about new features can be found in the News section on the homepage. You can also subscribe to the newsletter with information about important changes in the system.
faq.q10: How do I report a bug or have a suggestion for improvement?
faq.a10: Bugs and suggestions for improvements can be reported through the contact form or by email to the address listed in the Contacts section. We appreciate your feedback and strive to continuously improve our services.
faq.moreQuestionsSubtitle:
Didn't find the answer to your question?
We're happy to help!

amcrPas.hero.title: AMCR-PAS
amcrPas.hero.subtitle: Portal for Amateur Collaborators and Independent Finds Registration
amcrPas.hero.intro: Application for recording and managing archaeological finds:
amcrPas.about.label: About the project
amcrPas.about.title: What is AMCR-PAS?
amcrPas.about.description: AMCR-PAS (Portal for Amateur Collaborators) is a specialized application for metal detectorists and other amateur archaeology enthusiasts. It enables simple and quick reporting of archaeological finds, their documentation and communication with professional institutions. The system helps protect archaeological heritage while supporting constructive collaboration between amateurs and professional archaeologists.
amcrPas.usefulInfo.title: Useful Information
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item1.title: Getting Started
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item1.description: Registration in the system is simple and quick. After approval, you'll gain access to find reporting and communication with archaeological institutions.
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item2.title: Find Documentation
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item2.description: Learn how to properly document finds - photography, GPS location, context description and other important information.
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item3.title: Legal Framework
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item3.description: Familiarize yourself with the legal obligations of detectorists, conditions for using metal detectors and rules for reporting archaeological finds.
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item4.title: Institutional Cooperation
amcrPas.usefulInfo.item4.description: How to effectively collaborate with museums, archaeological institutes and other professional institutions in protecting archaeological heritage.

amcrPas.blog.post5.title: Winter Detecting
amcrPas.blog.post5.excerpt: Tips and tricks for effective metal detecting during winter months.
amcrPas.faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
amcrPas.faq.q1: How can I register for AMCR-PAS?
amcrPas.faq.a1: To register, contact an authorized archaeological organization in your region. After agreement, an archaeologist will guide you through the registration process.
amcrPas.faq.q2: Do I need a detector license?
amcrPas.faq.a2: Yes, for legal use of a metal detector in the Czech Republic, you must follow the heritage protection law and cooperate with an archaeological institution.
amcrPas.faq.q3: How do I report a find?
amcrPas.faq.a3: You report finds directly in the AMCR-PAS portal after logging in. The system will guide you through find documentation including photos and GPS location.
amcrPas.faq.q4: Do I have to hand over all finds?
amcrPas.faq.a4: Yes, according to law, archaeological finds are state property and must be handed over to a museum or other authorized institution.
amcrPas.faq.q5: Where can I search with a detector?
amcrPas.faq.a5: You can only search within professionally led archaeological excavations or with permission from an archaeological institution at pre-agreed sites.
amcrPas.faq.moreQuestionsSubtitle:
Didn't find the answer to your question?
We're happy to help!
